paragraphs.text_content: This module focuses on an important aspect of machine learning (ML) engineering: choosing the right modeling approach. In this module, you explore the various layers of the AWS ML stack and learn how to use AWS AI services to solve common business challenges. The module covers strategies for selecting appropriate models using Amazon SageMaker AI, and delves into the importance of interpretability in model selection. By the end of this module, you will have a comprehensive understanding of how to make informed decisions when choosing ML models for your projects.

This module focuses on an important aspect of machine learning (ML) engineering: choosing the right modeling approach. In this module, you explore the various layers of the AWS ML stack and learn how to use AWS AI services to solve common business challenges. The module covers strategies for selecting appropriate models using Amazon SageMaker AI, and delves into the importance of interpretability in model selection. By the end of this module, you will have a comprehensive understanding of how to make informed decisions when choosing ML models for your projects.

|Explain that this course covers how AWS services support ML engineers in each stage.
|Highlight where security considerations fit into the ML lifecycle.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
Security is a significant consideration throughout the entire machine learning lifecycle. In this module, you learn how to implement security measures at various stages of ML development and deployment on AWS:
Data collection and preparation: Secure data storage and access controls are important when gathering and preprocessing data for ML models.
Model development and training: Protecting your training environment and ensuring the integrity of your model during development is essential.
Model deployment and inference: Securing endpoints and managing access to deployed models help prevent unauthorized use or tampering.
Monitoring and maintenance: Continuous security monitoring and updates are necessary to maintain the integrity and performance of your ML systems over time.
By integrating security practices throughout the ML lifecycle, you create a robust and trustworthy environment for your machine learning projects on AWS.

|STUDENT NOTES:
Security is a significant consideration throughout the entire machine learning lifecycle. In this module, you learn how to implement security measures at various stages of ML development and deployment on AWS:
• Data collection and preparation: Secure data storage and access controls are important when gathering and preprocessing data for ML models.
• Model development and training: Protecting your training environment and ensuring the integrity of your model during development is essential.
• Model deployment and inference: Securing endpoints and managing access to deployed models help prevent unauthorized use or tampering.
• Monitoring and maintenance: Continuous security monitoring and updates are necessary to maintain the integrity and performance of your ML systems over time.
By integrating security practices throughout the ML lifecycle, you create a robust and trustworthy environment for your machine learning projects on AWS.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~No image on this slide.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Introduce Amazon SageMaker AI built-in algorithms.
|Highlight different categories (supervised, unsupervised, etc.).
|Mention ability to bring custom algorithms.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
Amazon SageMaker AI provides a comprehensive suite of built-in algorithms that cover a wide range of ML tasks. These algorithms are preconfigured and optimized for efficient training and deployment, so you can quickly build and deploy models without the need for extensive customization.
In addition to the built-in algorithms, with SageMaker AI you can also bring your own custom algorithms or use pre-trained models from the AWS Marketplace. With this flexibility, you can choose the most appropriate solution for your specific business needs.

|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
• |Introduce Amazon SageMaker AI built-in algorithms.
• |Highlight different categories (supervised, unsupervised, etc.).
• |Mention ability to bring custom algorithms.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
Amazon SageMaker AI provides a comprehensive suite of built-in algorithms that cover a wide range of ML tasks. These algorithms are preconfigured and optimized for efficient training and deployment, so you can quickly build and deploy models without the need for extensive customization.
In addition to the built-in algorithms, with SageMaker AI you can also bring your own custom algorithms or use pre-trained models from the AWS Marketplace. With this flexibility, you can choose the most appropriate solution for your specific business needs.

|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Highlight model development as a key step.
|Explain transition from data preparation.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
The ML lifecycle represents the complete journey of a machine learning project, from defining business goals through to monitoring deployed solutions. This module focuses specifically on the model development phase, where you learn about the built-in algorithms in Amazon SageMaker AI and how to choose the right ones for different business problems.
The model development process itself follows a specific workflow: beginning with prepared data, selecting an appropriate algorithm, implementing the training process, evaluating test results, and producing an output model. Each step in this process requires careful consideration to help you make making the best use of the capabilities of SageMaker AI to solve your ML challenges.

|Instructor notes
|Structured data (vs unstructured data)
|Supervised (vs unsupervised, reinforcement learning)
|Flip to the slide with supervised algorithms tree
|Recommendation model type
|Factorization machine
||STUDENT NOTES
Activity scenario: Ecommerce recommendation discussion
A large online retailer wants to enhance their product recommendation system. They have access to the following:
Customer purchase history (what items were bought together)
Browsing patterns (time spent on pages and items viewed)
Click-through data (what recommendations were clicked)
Consider different modeling approaches:
Before implementing a specific algorithm, it’s important to evaluate various modeling paradigms to determine which best aligns with the unique data characteristics and business requirements.
Supervised learning approaches:
Using historical purchase data to predict future purchases
Learning from labeled data of successful recommendations
Training on known customer-product matches
Unsupervised learning approaches:
Finding natural groupings of similar products
Discovering patterns in customer browsing behavior
Identifying hidden relationships between products
Different model types to consider:
Linear models for straightforward prediction patterns
Tree-based models for complex decision rules
Neural networks for deep pattern recognition
Matrix-based models for customer-product relationships
Considerations:
1. What is the nature of your data?
Is it structured or unstructured?
Is it numerical, categorical, or mixed?
How many features does your dataset have?
2. What is the size of your dataset?
Do you have a small, medium, or large amount of data?
Is your dataset likely to grow significantly over time?
3. What is the complexity of the relationships in your data?
Are the relationships likely to be linear or non-linear?
Are there many interactions between features?
4. How interpretable does your model need to be?
Do you need to explain the model's decisions to stakeholders?
Is black-box prediction acceptable, or do you need transparency?
5. What is your computational budget?
Do you have access to powerful computing resources?
Is training time a deciding factor?
6. What is the desired prediction speed?
Do you need real-time predictions?
Is batch processing acceptable?

paragraphs.text_content: SageMaker AI offers various model types for different use cases, including structured data analysis, computer vision, NLP, and time series forecasting. For image and video processing, it provides CNNs, ResNets, and vision transformers, enabling tasks like classification, object detection, and segmentation. ResNets have improved image recognition by allowing training of deeper networks through residual learning frameworks.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~A set of icons representing different model types: a line graph, a tree diagram, a neural network, clusters of data points, a bar chart, a wave pattern, an image with a bounding box, and a sequence of connected squares.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Briefly review the different model types available in SageMaker AI.
|Highlight the diversity of options for various use cases.
|Encourage students to explore the documentation for more details.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
Generalized linear models: These are fast, interpretable models like linear/logistic regression and SVMs, which are less flexible than more complex models.
Tree-based models: This category includes boosted trees, random forests, and decision trees, which are more accurate than linear models but require slightly longer training times.
Neural networks: MLPs, CNNs, RNNs, and transformers can model complex relationships but require large datasets, have slower training times, and are harder to interpret.
Clustering: Algorithms like K-means and DBSCAN group data with high intra-group and low inter-group similarity, primarily used for exploratory analysis and unsupervised learning.
Matrix factorization: This includes techniques like PCA, which are used for recommender systems, dimensionality reduction, and feature learning.
Forecasting: Time series models such as ARIMA and DeepAR are designed for predicting future values based on historical data.
Computer vision models: CNNs, ResNets, and vision transformers are specialized for image and video processing, classification, detection, and segmentation tasks.
Sequence models: RNNs, LSTMs, and transformers are ideal for processing sequential data, particularly in NLP and time series analysis.
SageMaker AI offers various model types for different use cases, including structured data analysis, computer vision, NLP, and time series forecasting. For image and video processing, it provides CNNs, ResNets, and vision transformers, enabling tasks like classification, object detection, and segmentation. ResNets have improved image recognition by allowing training of deeper networks through residual learning frameworks.
slide_analyses.formatted_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~A set of icons representing different model types: a line graph, a tree diagram, a neural network, clusters of data points, a bar chart, a wave pattern, an image with a bounding box, and a sequence of connected squares.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
• |Briefly review the different model types available in SageMaker AI.
• |Highlight the diversity of options for various use cases.
• |Encourage students to explore the documentation for more details.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
Generalized linear models: These are fast, interpretable models like linear/logistic regression and SVMs, which are less flexible than more complex models.
Tree-based models: This category includes boosted trees, random forests, and decision trees, which are more accurate than linear models but require slightly longer training times.
Neural networks: MLPs, CNNs, RNNs, and transformers can model complex relationships but require large datasets, have slower training times, and are harder to interpret.
Clustering: Algorithms like K-means and DBSCAN group data with high intra-group and low inter-group similarity, primarily used for exploratory analysis and unsupervised learning.
Matrix factorization: This includes techniques like PCA, which are used for recommender systems, dimensionality reduction, and feature learning.
Forecasting: Time series models such as ARIMA and DeepAR are designed for predicting future values based on historical data.
Computer vision models: CNNs, ResNets, and vision transformers are specialized for image and video processing, classification, detection, and segmentation tasks.
Sequence models: RNNs, LSTMs, and transformers are ideal for processing sequential data, particularly in NLP and time series analysis.
SageMaker AI offers various model types for different use cases, including structured data analysis, computer vision, NLP, and time series forecasting. For image and video processing, it provides CNNs, ResNets, and vision transformers, enabling tasks like classification, object detection, and segmentation. ResNets have improved image recognition by allowing training of deeper networks through residual learning frameworks.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~A diagram showing four options for algorithms in SageMaker: Built-in algorithms, Script mode, AWS Marketplace, and Bring your own.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Explain the four options for algorithms in SageMaker AI.
|Highlight the flexibility and choice provided.
|Mention the ability to use custom algorithms.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
When building ML models with SageMaker AI, you have several options to choose how you implement training algorithms. These options provide flexibility for you to select the approach that best suits your specific requirements:
Bring your own: If you have proprietary algorithms or models developed in-house, you can bring them to SageMaker AI and use its training, deployment, and management capabilities.
Script mode: If you prefer to use your own custom code or use popular open-source frameworks such as TensorFlow, PyTorch, or Apache MXNet, you can write scripts and run them within the SageMaker AI managed environment.
Built-in algorithms: SageMaker AI offers a wide range of prebuilt and optimized algorithms for various ML tasks, such as supervised learning, unsupervised learning, computer vision, and natural language processing.
AWS Marketplace: SageMaker AI integrates with the AWS Marketplace, so you can subscribe to and use third-party algorithms and model packages developed by various providers, including industry-leading companies and research institutions.
This range of options empowers you to choose the approach that best aligns with your specific use case, existing codebase, and expertise.
slide_analyses.formatted_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~A diagram showing four options for algorithms in SageMaker: Built-in algorithms, Script mode, AWS Marketplace, and Bring your own.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
• |Explain the four options for algorithms in SageMaker AI.
• |Highlight the flexibility and choice provided.
• |Mention the ability to use custom algorithms.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
When building ML models with SageMaker AI, you have several options to choose how you implement training algorithms. These options provide flexibility for you to select the approach that best suits your specific requirements:
• Bring your own: If you have proprietary algorithms or models developed in-house, you can bring them to SageMaker AI and use its training, deployment, and management capabilities.
• Script mode: If you prefer to use your own custom code or use popular open-source frameworks such as TensorFlow, PyTorch, or Apache MXNet, you can write scripts and run them within the SageMaker AI managed environment.
• Built-in algorithms: SageMaker AI offers a wide range of prebuilt and optimized algorithms for various ML tasks, such as supervised learning, unsupervised learning, computer vision, and natural language processing.
• AWS Marketplace: SageMaker AI integrates with the AWS Marketplace, so you can subscribe to and use third-party algorithms and model packages developed by various providers, including industry-leading companies and research institutions.
This range of options empowers you to choose the approach that best aligns with your specific use case, existing codebase, and expertise.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~No image on this slide.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Discuss the various factors to consider when selecting algorithms.
|Emphasize the importance of understanding the problem and data characteristics.
|Highlight the trade-offs between different considerations.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
Selecting the appropriate ML algorithm is an essential step in building accurate and effective models. When choosing an algorithm in SageMaker AI, you must consider several key factors:
Problem type – The first step is to identify the type of problem you're trying to solve, such as classification, regression, clustering, or recommendation systems. Some algorithms are better suited for specific problem types, and understanding the nature of your problem will guide your algorithm selection.
Data characteristics – Analyze your data to understand its size, dimensionality, noise levels, and potential biases. This information can help you choose an appropriate model architecture and algorithm that can effectively handle the characteristics of your data.
Performance requirements – Consider the desired performance metrics for your model, such as accuracy, precision, recall, or F1-score. Some algorithms might prioritize one metric over others, so choose accordingly based on your specific performance goals.
Training time and computational resources – Different models have varying computational requirements during the training phase. Consider the available resources, such as CPU, graphics processing unit (GPU), and memory, and the time constraints for your project when selecting an algorithm.
Interpretability: – If interpretability is important for your use case, you might want to choose simpler models like linear or tree-based algorithms over complex deep learning models, which can be more challenging to interpret and explain.
By carefully considering these factors, you can select the most appropriate algorithm for your ML task, to help build optimal performance, efficiency, and alignment into your business objectives.

|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
• |Discuss the various factors to consider when selecting algorithms.
• |Emphasize the importance of understanding the problem and data characteristics.
• |Highlight the trade-offs between different considerations.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
Selecting the appropriate ML algorithm is an essential step in building accurate and effective models. When choosing an algorithm in SageMaker AI, you must consider several key factors:
• Problem type – The first step is to identify the type of problem you're trying to solve, such as classification, regression, clustering, or recommendation systems. Some algorithms are better suited for specific problem types, and understanding the nature of your problem will guide your algorithm selection.
• Data characteristics – Analyze your data to understand its size, dimensionality, noise levels, and potential biases. This information can help you choose an appropriate model architecture and algorithm that can effectively handle the characteristics of your data.
• Performance requirements – Consider the desired performance metrics for your model, such as accuracy, precision, recall, or F1-score. Some algorithms might prioritize one metric over others, so choose accordingly based on your specific performance goals.
• Training time and computational resources – Different models have varying computational requirements during the training phase. Consider the available resources, such as CPU, graphics processing unit (GPU), and memory, and the time constraints for your project when selecting an algorithm.
• Interpretability: – If interpretability is important for your use case, you might want to choose simpler models like linear or tree-based algorithms over complex deep learning models, which can be more challenging to interpret and explain.
By carefully considering these factors, you can select the most appropriate algorithm for your ML task, to help build optimal performance, efficiency, and alignment into your business objectives.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~Ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/model-selection.html
~
~Alt text:
~A conceptual diagram illustrating various factors to consider in model selection, such as data characteristics, performance requirements, interpretability, and computational resources.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Discuss key factors in model selection.
|Emphasize importance of balancing different considerations.
|Provide examples of trade-offs in real-world scenarios.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
Selecting the appropriate ML model is an important decision that impacts the success of your project. Several key considerations should guide your choice.
Data characteristics play an important role. The size, dimensionality, and quality of your dataset can determine which models are feasible and likely to perform well. For instance, deep learning models often require large amounts of data, while simpler models might be more appropriate for smaller datasets.
Performance requirements are another vital factor. Consider what metrics are most important for your specific use case (for example, accuracy, precision, and recall) and how they align with different model types. However, it's essential to balance performance with other considerations such as interpretability and computational resources.
Interpretability is particularly important in domains where understanding the model's decision-making process is essential, such as healthcare or finance. Some models, such as decision trees, offer high interpretability, while others, like neural networks, can be more opaque.
You should also consider computational resources available for training and inference. Some models require significant processing power or memory, which might impact deployment options and costs.
Ultimately, the best model often involves trade-offs between these factors, and the optimal choice depends on the specific requirements and constraints of your project.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/autopilot-automate-model-development.html
~
~Alt text:
~A flowchart showing the steps of the Amazon SageMaker Autopilot process: Data analysis, Feature engineering, Model selection, Hyperparameter optimization, and Model evaluation.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Introduce Amazon SageMaker Autopilot.
|Explain the automated ML process.
|Highlight benefits for both novice and experienced users.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
The powerful automation capabilities of Amazon SageMaker Autopilot are deeply integrated throughout the SageMaker AI systems, making advanced ML accessible across multiple interfaces.
In Amazon SageMaker Canvas, SageMaker Autopilot powers the no-code model building experience, so that business users can create predictions through a visual interface without writing a single line of code. Within Amazon SageMaker Studio, data scientists can launch SageMaker Autopilot jobs directly from their notebooks, while the same functionality is available programmatically through the SageMaker Python SDK. This unified automated machine learning (AutoML) engine dramatically accelerates ML model development by handling feature engineering, algorithm selection, and hyperparameter optimization, regardless of which entry point you choose.
With SageMaker Autopilot, teams without specialized machine learning expertise can build production-quality models. Business analysts, developers, and domain experts can use AutoML capabilities through an intuitive interface without needing deep knowledge of algorithm selection or feature transformations. Because of this democratization, organizations can apply machine learning across departments that previously lacked the technical resources.
Unlike black-box solutions, SageMaker Autopilot provides complete transparency by generating notebooks that document the entire ML pipeline, so users can understand and customize the process. The system automatically optimizes resource allocation and parallelizes experiments, significantly reducing costs compared to manual approaches. When ready for deployment, models can be pushed to production endpoints with a single click, complete with inference code and scaling configurations—eliminating the traditional complexity of operationalizing machine learning models.

• |Highlight benefits for both novice and experienced users.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
The powerful automation capabilities of Amazon SageMaker Autopilot are deeply integrated throughout the SageMaker AI systems, making advanced ML accessible across multiple interfaces.
In Amazon SageMaker Canvas, SageMaker Autopilot powers the no-code model building experience, so that business users can create predictions through a visual interface without writing a single line of code. Within Amazon SageMaker Studio, data scientists can launch SageMaker Autopilot jobs directly from their notebooks, while the same functionality is available programmatically through the SageMaker Python SDK. This unified automated machine learning (AutoML) engine dramatically accelerates ML model development by handling feature engineering, algorithm selection, and hyperparameter optimization, regardless of which entry point you choose.
With SageMaker Autopilot, teams without specialized machine learning expertise can build production-quality models. Business analysts, developers, and domain experts can use AutoML capabilities through an intuitive interface without needing deep knowledge of algorithm selection or feature transformations. Because of this democratization, organizations can apply machine learning across departments that previously lacked the technical resources.
Unlike black-box solutions, SageMaker Autopilot provides complete transparency by generating notebooks that document the entire ML pipeline, so users can understand and customize the process. The system automatically optimizes resource allocation and parallelizes experiments, significantly reducing costs compared to manual approaches. When ready for deployment, models can be pushed to production endpoints with a single click, complete with inference code and scaling configurations—eliminating the traditional complexity of operationalizing machine learning models.

~A flowchart showing the steps to implement AutoML using SageMaker Autopilot: Data preparation, Job creation, Candidate generation, Model training, and Model deployment.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Explain the process of using SageMaker Autopilot.
|Highlight key steps in the AutoML workflow.
|Discuss the benefits of using Autopilot for ML projects.
||
|STUDENT NOTES:
Implementing AutoML using Amazon SageMaker Autopilot in SageMaker Studio involves these streamlined steps:
Data preparation: Upload your tabular dataset in comma separated value (CSV) or Parquet format to Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3), or import it directly into SageMaker Studio from local files.
Create a SageMaker Autopilot experiment: In SageMaker Studio, specify the dataset location, target column to predict, and optionally select the problem type (classification or regression). Configure additional settings such as maximum runtime and resource limits.
Launch and monitor: Start the experiment and track progress through the SageMaker Studio interface. SageMaker Autopilot automatically analyzes your data, generates features, selects algorithms, and optimizes hyperparameters.
Explore candidates: Review the performance metrics of different model candidates in the experiment dashboard. Examine the automatically generated data exploration and model explanation notebooks for insights.
Deploy the best model: Deploy your chosen model to a SageMaker AI endpoint with a few clicks, or export predictions for batch processing.
By using SageMaker Autopilot within SageMaker Studio, you gain the benefits of automated ML with the transparency of generated notebooks that document each step in the process, all within a unified data science environment.  A similar process is used within SageMaker Canvas.

~Alt text:

~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
• |Explain the process of using SageMaker Autopilot.
• |Highlight key steps in the AutoML workflow.
• |Discuss the benefits of using Autopilot for ML projects.
||
|STUDENT NOTES:
Implementing AutoML using Amazon SageMaker Autopilot in SageMaker Studio involves these streamlined steps:
1. Data preparation: Upload your tabular dataset in comma separated value (CSV) or Parquet format to Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3), or import it directly into SageMaker Studio from local files.
1. Create a SageMaker Autopilot experiment: In SageMaker Studio, specify the dataset location, target column to predict, and optionally select the problem type (classification or regression). Configure additional settings such as maximum runtime and resource limits.
1. Launch and monitor: Start the experiment and track progress through the SageMaker Studio interface. SageMaker Autopilot automatically analyzes your data, generates features, selects algorithms, and optimizes hyperparameters.
1. Explore candidates: Review the performance metrics of different model candidates in the experiment dashboard. Examine the automatically generated data exploration and model explanation notebooks for insights.
1. Deploy the best model: Deploy your chosen model to a SageMaker AI endpoint with a few clicks, or export predictions for batch processing.
By using SageMaker Autopilot within SageMaker Studio, you gain the benefits of automated ML with the transparency of generated notebooks that document each step in the process, all within a unified data science environment.  A similar process is used within SageMaker Canvas.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~Ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/use-auto-ml.html
~
~Alt text:
~A diagram showing different interpretability strategies: Interpretable Model Approximation, Local Interpretability, Modular Design, and Ensemble Methods.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Methods to run SageMaker Autopilot.
|Pros and cons of each.
|Examples of when to use each.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
You can run Amazon SageMaker Autopilot from multiple SageMaker AI features.
SageMaker Canvas provides a no-code visual interface that incorporates the automated machine learning capabilities of SageMaker Autopilot, so business analysts and domain experts without coding experience can build models. Users can upload data, specify the prediction target, and SageMaker Canvas uses SageMaker Autopilot to generate optimized models.
SageMaker Studio offers data scientists and developers a comprehensive integrated development environment (IDE) with a visual interface for creating, managing, and analyzing SageMaker Autopilot experiments. The SageMaker Studio dashboard displays model leaderboards and performance metrics, and provides access to the automatically generated notebooks and model explanations.
Amazon SageMaker Pipelines can incorporate SageMaker Autopilot jobs as steps in automated ML workflows, enabling orchestration of the entire ML lifecycle from data preparation through model deployment, with SageMaker Autopilot handling the model building phase.
For programmatic access, the SageMaker AI Python SDK provides the AutoML class for fine-grained control over SageMaker Autopilot experiments, while the SageMaker AI APIs help build integration into custom applications and continuous integration and delivery (CI/CD) systems.
After models are deployed, you can use Amazon SageMaker Model Monitor to track data and prediction drift, helping to build models generated by SageMaker Autopilot that maintain quality in production environments. When drift is detected, new SageMaker Autopilot experiments can be initiated to retrain models.
slide_analyses.formatted_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~Ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/use-auto-ml.html
~
~Alt text:
~A diagram showing different interpretability strategies: Interpretable Model Approximation, Local Interpretability, Modular Design, and Ensemble Methods.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
• |Methods to run SageMaker Autopilot.
• |Pros and cons of each.
• |Examples of when to use each.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
You can run Amazon SageMaker Autopilot from multiple SageMaker AI features.
SageMaker Canvas provides a no-code visual interface that incorporates the automated machine learning capabilities of SageMaker Autopilot, so business analysts and domain experts without coding experience can build models. Users can upload data, specify the prediction target, and SageMaker Canvas uses SageMaker Autopilot to generate optimized models.
SageMaker Studio offers data scientists and developers a comprehensive integrated development environment (IDE) with a visual interface for creating, managing, and analyzing SageMaker Autopilot experiments. The SageMaker Studio dashboard displays model leaderboards and performance metrics, and provides access to the automatically generated notebooks and model explanations.
Amazon SageMaker Pipelines can incorporate SageMaker Autopilot jobs as steps in automated ML workflows, enabling orchestration of the entire ML lifecycle from data preparation through model deployment, with SageMaker Autopilot handling the model building phase.
For programmatic access, the SageMaker AI Python SDK provides the AutoML class for fine-grained control over SageMaker Autopilot experiments, while the SageMaker AI APIs help build integration into custom applications and continuous integration and delivery (CI/CD) systems.
After models are deployed, you can use Amazon SageMaker Model Monitor to track data and prediction drift, helping to build models generated by SageMaker Autopilot that maintain quality in production environments. When drift is detected, new SageMaker Autopilot experiments can be initiated to retrain models.

~Developer Notes:
~https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~No image on this slide.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|20 minutes.
|Students will likely be eager to learn more about the various built-in algorithms available in Amazon SageMaker. DO NOT GO DEEP into each algorithm.
|We'll take some extra time to explain XGBoost in more depth, because we use it in the lab.
|Slides 18-20 walk students through the considerations involved when moving through the decision tree.|Slides 21-23: Move through these quickly and not deeply.  Remember to refer students to the algorithms page int eh SageMaker docs.
|Direct students to the comprehensive documentation on the SageMaker AI built-in algorithms at https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html. |Encourage them to bookmark this page and feel comfortable referencing it when selecting algorithms for their own projects.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
After exploring and analyzing your data, you're ready to build an ML model. Selecting the appropriate training algorithm is an important step in this process, because it directly impacts the model's performance, accuracy, and suitability for your specific use case.
SageMaker AI provides a comprehensive suite of built-in algorithms, pre-trained models, and pre-built solution templates to help data scientists and ML practitioners get started quickly. Using these features, you can train and deploy ML models efficiently, without the need to extensively customize or develop algorithms.
By using these built-in algorithms, you can significantly reduce the time and effort required to develop and deploy ML models.

|STUDENT NOTES:
After exploring and analyzing your data, you're ready to build an ML model. Selecting the appropriate training algorithm is an important step in this process, because it directly impacts the model's performance, accuracy, and suitability for your specific use case.
SageMaker AI provides a comprehensive suite of built-in algorithms, pre-trained models, and pre-built solution templates to help data scientists and ML practitioners get started quickly. Using these features, you can train and deploy ML models efficiently, without the need to extensively customize or develop algorithms.
By using these built-in algorithms, you can significantly reduce the time and effort required to develop and deploy ML models.

~
~Alt text:
~No image on this slide.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Introduce Amazon SageMaker AI built-in algorithms.
|Highlight different categories (supervised, unsupervised, etc.).
|Mention ability to bring custom algorithms.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
SageMaker AI built-in algorithms are pre-configured and optimized for efficient training and deployment, so you can quickly build and deploy models without the need for extensive customization.
The SageMaker AI built-in algorithms are organized into several categories, including supervised learning (for classification and regression tasks), unsupervised learning (for clustering and dimensionality reduction), text and speech analysis, computer vision, and reinforcement learning. Each category offers multiple algorithm options tailored to specific use cases.
In addition to the built-in algorithms, with SageMaker AI you can also bring your own custom algorithms or use pre-trained models from the AWS Marketplace. With this flexibility, you choose the most appropriate solution for your specific business needs.
For more information about the SageMaker AI built-in algorithms, see “Built-in algorithms and pretrained models in Amazon SageMaker” in the Amazon SageMaker AI Developer Guide (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html).

|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
• |Introduce Amazon SageMaker AI built-in algorithms.
• |Highlight different categories (supervised, unsupervised, etc.).
• |Mention ability to bring custom algorithms.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
SageMaker AI built-in algorithms are pre-configured and optimized for efficient training and deployment, so you can quickly build and deploy models without the need for extensive customization.
The SageMaker AI built-in algorithms are organized into several categories, including supervised learning (for classification and regression tasks), unsupervised learning (for clustering and dimensionality reduction), text and speech analysis, computer vision, and reinforcement learning. Each category offers multiple algorithm options tailored to specific use cases.
In addition to the built-in algorithms, with SageMaker AI you can also bring your own custom algorithms or use pre-trained models from the AWS Marketplace. With this flexibility, you choose the most appropriate solution for your specific business needs.
For more information about the SageMaker AI built-in algorithms, see “Built-in algorithms and pretrained models in Amazon SageMaker” in the Amazon SageMaker AI Developer Guide (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html).

paragraphs.text_content: Amazon SageMaker JumpStart offers a variety of pre-trained models and pre-built solution templates for popular problem types, including image classification, tabular classification and regression, text analysis, object detection, and natural language processing. These pre-trained models and templates can serve as a starting point for your projects, accelerating the development process.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~Alt text: Supervised learning algorithm decision tree. highlighting the choices between classification, regression and recommendation algorithms.
~Ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Introduce the built-in algorithms for supervised learning.
|Highlight the different model types and their applications.
|Mention the pre-trained models and solution templates available.|
|** Animation:  Highlight around XGBoost.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
SageMaker AI provides several built-in, general-purpose algorithms that developers can use for supervised learning tasks, such as classification and regression problems. These algorithms are preconfigured and optimized for efficient training and deployment, so you can quickly build and deploy models without the need for extensive customization.
Pre-trained models and solution templates
Amazon SageMaker JumpStart offers a variety of pre-trained models and pre-built solution templates for popular problem types, including image classification, tabular classification and regression, text analysis, object detection, and natural language processing. These pre-trained models and templates can serve as a starting point for your projects, accelerating the development process.
Supervised learning algorithms
The following built-in algorithms cover a wide range of model types, including linear models, tree-based models, neural networks, and ensemble methods.
You can choose the most appropriate algorithm for your specific use case and data characteristics:
AutoGluon-Tabular: Ensembles models for classification and regression (ensemble learning)
CatBoost: Implements gradient-boosted trees with ordered boosting (gradient-boosted trees)
Factorization Machines: Captures interactions in high-dimensional sparse datasets (factorization machines)
K-nearest neighbors (k-NN): Uses nearest labeled points for classification and regression (instance-based learning)
Light Gradient-Boosting Machine (LightGBM): Applies efficient gradient-boosted trees with Gradient-Based One-Side Sampling (GOSS) and Exclusive Feature Bundling (EFB) (gradient-boosted trees)
Linear learner: Employs linear function for regression or classification (linear models)
TabTransformer: Utilizes deep tabular data modeling with Transformers (Transformers)
eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost): Implements ensemble of gradient-boosted trees (gradient-boosted trees)

|
|STUDENT NOTES:
SageMaker AI provides several built-in, general-purpose algorithms that developers can use for supervised learning tasks, such as classification and regression problems. These algorithms are preconfigured and optimized for efficient training and deployment, so you can quickly build and deploy models without the need for extensive customization.
Pre-trained models and solution templates
Amazon SageMaker JumpStart offers a variety of pre-trained models and pre-built solution templates for popular problem types, including image classification, tabular classification and regression, text analysis, object detection, and natural language processing. These pre-trained models and templates can serve as a starting point for your projects, accelerating the development process.
Supervised learning algorithms
The following built-in algorithms cover a wide range of model types, including linear models, tree-based models, neural networks, and ensemble methods.
You can choose the most appropriate algorithm for your specific use case and data characteristics:
• AutoGluon-Tabular: Ensembles models for classification and regression (ensemble learning)
• CatBoost: Implements gradient-boosted trees with ordered boosting (gradient-boosted trees)
• Factorization Machines: Captures interactions in high-dimensional sparse datasets (factorization machines)
• K-nearest neighbors (k-NN): Uses nearest labeled points for classification and regression (instance-based learning)
• Light Gradient-Boosting Machine (LightGBM): Applies efficient gradient-boosted trees with Gradient-Based One-Side Sampling (GOSS) and Exclusive Feature Bundling (EFB) (gradient-boosted trees)
• Linear learner: Employs linear function for regression or classification (linear models)
• TabTransformer: Utilizes deep tabular data modeling with Transformers (Transformers)
• eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost): Implements ensemble of gradient-boosted trees (gradient-boosted trees)

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~Ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~
~ |INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Explain the task of predicting income based on demographics.
|Guide students through identifying the ML domain and problem type.
|Demonstrate how to find and list relevant SageMaker AI built-in algorithms.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
This guided activity focuses on a common ML task: predicting whether an individual's income is below a certain threshold. You're provided with a CSV dataset containing demographic information and income data. This scenario is typical in many real-world applications, such as targeted marketing or financial services.
To approach this problem, you need to do the following:
Identify the ML domain and problem type: Analyze the given information to determine whether this is a supervised or unsupervised learning problem and whether it's a classification or regression task.
List relevant SageMaker AI built-in algorithms: Use the provided QR code to access the SageMaker AI documentation and identify algorithms suitable for the problem type you've determined.
When selecting algorithms, consider factors such as data characteristics, model interpretability requirements, and performance metrics relevant to your specific use case. This process is important for building effective ML solutions in SageMaker AI.

~Alt text:
~
~ |INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
• |Explain the task of predicting income based on demographics.
• |Guide students through identifying the ML domain and problem type.
• |Demonstrate how to find and list relevant SageMaker AI built-in algorithms.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
This guided activity focuses on a common ML task: predicting whether an individual's income is below a certain threshold. You're provided with a CSV dataset containing demographic information and income data. This scenario is typical in many real-world applications, such as targeted marketing or financial services.
To approach this problem, you need to do the following:
1. Identify the ML domain and problem type: Analyze the given information to determine whether this is a supervised or unsupervised learning problem and whether it's a classification or regression task.
1. List relevant SageMaker AI built-in algorithms: Use the provided QR code to access the SageMaker AI documentation and identify algorithms suitable for the problem type you've determined.
When selecting algorithms, consider factors such as data characteristics, model interpretability requirements, and performance metrics relevant to your specific use case. This process is important for building effective ML solutions in SageMaker AI.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes: ~Ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~This slide shows the solution to the guided activity, identifying the problem as supervised learning and binary classification, with sample algorithms listed, including CatBoost, Linear learner, and XGBoost.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Review the problem type identification: supervised learning and binary classification.
|Discuss the sample algorithms provided: CatBoost, Linear learner, and XGBoost.
|Explain why these algorithms are suitable for binary classification tasks.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
The solution to the guided activity reveals that predicting an income above a threshold is a supervised learning problem, specifically a binary classification task. This is because you have labeled data (income values) and are predicting one of two outcomes (above or below the threshold).
Sample algorithms suitable for this task include the following:
CatBoost: Efficient for handling categorical features
Linear learner: Good for linearly separable data and interpretable models
XGBoost: Powerful for complex relationships in data
These algorithms are well-suited for binary classification in SageMaker AI because of their ability to handle various data types and their proven performance in similar tasks. When choosing between them, consider factors such as dataset size, feature types, model explainability requirements, and computational resources available.

~Alt text:
~This slide shows the solution to the guided activity, identifying the problem as supervised learning and binary classification, with sample algorithms listed, including CatBoost, Linear learner, and XGBoost.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
• |Review the problem type identification: supervised learning and binary classification.
• |Discuss the sample algorithms provided: CatBoost, Linear learner, and XGBoost.
• |Explain why these algorithms are suitable for binary classification tasks.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
The solution to the guided activity reveals that predicting an income above a threshold is a supervised learning problem, specifically a binary classification task. This is because you have labeled data (income values) and are predicting one of two outcomes (above or below the threshold).
Sample algorithms suitable for this task include the following:
• CatBoost: Efficient for handling categorical features
• Linear learner: Good for linearly separable data and interpretable models
• XGBoost: Powerful for complex relationships in data
These algorithms are well-suited for binary classification in SageMaker AI because of their ability to handle various data types and their proven performance in similar tasks. When choosing between them, consider factors such as dataset size, feature types, model explainability requirements, and computational resources available.

paragraphs.text_content: For clustering, the K-means algorithm groups similar data points together. Topic modeling is addressed by latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA), which discovers abstract topics in document collections, and Neural Topic Model (NTM), which uses neural networks to identify latent topics with potentially higher accuracy than traditional methods. The Object2Vec algorithm creates embeddings to capture relationships between objects in high-dimensional spaces.

paragraphs.formatted_output: For clustering, the K-means algorithm groups similar data points together. Topic modeling is addressed by latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA), which discovers abstract topics in document collections, and Neural Topic Model (NTM), which uses neural networks to identify latent topics with potentially higher accuracy than traditional methods. The Object2Vec algorithm creates embeddings to capture relationships between objects in high-dimensional spaces.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~Ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~A table listing SageMaker built-in algorithms for supervised learning, including AutoGluon-Tabular, CatBoost, Factorization Machines, k-NN, LightGBM, Linear learner, TabTransformer, and XGBoost.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Review key supervised learning algorithms offered by SageMaker AI.
|Highlight use cases for each algorithm.
|Discuss pros and cons of different algorithms.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
SageMaker AI offers a range of built-in algorithms for unsupervised learning tasks, so that developers can extract insights from unlabeled data. These algorithms fall into several categories.
For clustering, the K-means algorithm groups similar data points together. Topic modeling is addressed by latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA), which discovers abstract topics in document collections, and Neural Topic Model (NTM), which uses neural networks to identify latent topics with potentially higher accuracy than traditional methods. The Object2Vec algorithm creates embeddings to capture relationships between objects in high-dimensional spaces.
Anomaly detection is handled by the Random Cut Forest (RCF) algorithm, which identifies outliers in data streams, and IP Insights, which learns usage patterns of IP addresses. For dimensionality reduction, SageMaker AI provides principal component analysis (PCA), which reduces the number of features while preserving important information.
When choosing an unsupervised learning algorithm, consider the specific problem you're trying to solve, the structure of your data, and the interpretability requirements of your results. Unsupervised techniques are particularly valuable for exploratory data analysis and discovering hidden patterns in complex datasets.

|STUDENT NOTES:
SageMaker AI offers a range of built-in algorithms for unsupervised learning tasks, so that developers can extract insights from unlabeled data. These algorithms fall into several categories.
For clustering, the K-means algorithm groups similar data points together. Topic modeling is addressed by latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA), which discovers abstract topics in document collections, and Neural Topic Model (NTM), which uses neural networks to identify latent topics with potentially higher accuracy than traditional methods. The Object2Vec algorithm creates embeddings to capture relationships between objects in high-dimensional spaces.
Anomaly detection is handled by the Random Cut Forest (RCF) algorithm, which identifies outliers in data streams, and IP Insights, which learns usage patterns of IP addresses. For dimensionality reduction, SageMaker AI provides principal component analysis (PCA), which reduces the number of features while preserving important information.
When choosing an unsupervised learning algorithm, consider the specific problem you're trying to solve, the structure of your data, and the interpretability requirements of your results. Unsupervised techniques are particularly valuable for exploratory data analysis and discovering hidden patterns in complex datasets.

~Developer Notes:
~Ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~A diagram showing unsupervised learning categories (Clustering, Topic Modeling, Embeddings, Anomaly Detection, Dimensionality Reduction) with corresponding SageMaker algorithms listed under each category.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Explain key unsupervised learning algorithms in SageMaker AI.
|Discuss applications for each algorithm type.
|Compare strengths and limitations of different approaches.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
SageMaker AI provides specialized algorithms for processing text and speech data, which developers can use to tackle a wide range of natural language processing (NLP) tasks. For text analysis, SageMaker AI offers several powerful options.
BlazingText is a highly optimized implementation of Word2Vec and text classification algorithms, such as skip-gram and continuous bag of words (CBOW). BlazingText is suitable for large-scale NLP tasks. The Sequence-to-Sequence (seq2seq) algorithm is versatile, supporting applications such as machine translation and text summarization for both text and speech data.
For topic modeling, SageMaker AI provides two options: LDA and NTM. LDA is a probabilistic approach, while NTM uses neural networks for potentially more flexible topic discovery.
When working with speech data, the Sequence-to-Sequence algorithm can also be applied for tasks such as speech recognition and speech synthesis. When selecting an algorithm for text or speech processing, consider factors such as the specific NLP task, the size and nature of your dataset, and the required balance between model complexity and interpretability.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~Ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~A table showing SageMaker algorithms for text and speech data, categorized into Text (BlazingText, Sequence-to-Sequence, LDA, NTM) and Speech (Sequence-to-Sequence) with corresponding use cases listed.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Review SageMaker AI algorithms for text and speech processing.
|Explain key applications for each algorithm.
|Discuss considerations when choosing between algorithms.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
SageMaker AI provides specialized built-in algorithms for processing images, video, and time-series data. These algorithms are organized into distinct categories.
Image or video processing:
MXNet implementation for deep learning-based classification
TensorFlow implementation, offering an alternative approach
Object detection and classification:
MXNet-based detection for identifying and localizing objects
TensorFlow-based detection, providing another implementation option
Computer vision:
Semantic segmentation for pixel-level image understanding
Time series analysis:
DeepAR forecasting for predicting future values in time-series data
These algorithms help train various ML models for tasks such as the following:
Classifying images into predefined categories
Detecting and identifying objects within images or video
Segmenting images for detailed scene understanding
Making accurate predictions with time-series data
Choose the appropriate algorithm based on your specific use case and preferred deep learning framework (MXNet or TensorFlow).
slide_analyses.formatted_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~Ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~A table showing SageMaker algorithms for text and speech data, categorized into Text (BlazingText, Sequence-to-Sequence, LDA, NTM) and Speech (Sequence-to-Sequence) with corresponding use cases listed.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
• |Review SageMaker AI algorithms for text and speech processing.
• |Explain key applications for each algorithm.
• |Discuss considerations when choosing between algorithms.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
SageMaker AI provides specialized built-in algorithms for processing images, video, and time-series data. These algorithms are organized into distinct categories.
Image or video processing:
• MXNet implementation for deep learning-based classification
• TensorFlow implementation, offering an alternative approach
Object detection and classification:
• MXNet-based detection for identifying and localizing objects
• TensorFlow-based detection, providing another implementation option
Computer vision:
• Semantic segmentation for pixel-level image understanding
Time series analysis:
• DeepAR forecasting for predicting future values in time-series data
These algorithms help train various ML models for tasks such as the following:
• Classifying images into predefined categories
• Detecting and identifying objects within images or video
• Segmenting images for detailed scene understanding
• Making accurate predictions with time-series data
Choose the appropriate algorithm based on your specific use case and preferred deep learning framework (MXNet or TensorFlow).

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://aws.amazon.com/machine-learning/features/interpretability/
~https://aws.amazon.com/machine-learning/pricing/
~
~Alt text:
~Two icons representing interpretability (a magnifying glass) and cost (a dollar sign).
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Recap the importance of interpretability and cost considerations.
|Highlight the need to balance these factors with performance.
|Emphasize the role of domain knowledge and use case requirements.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
Interpretability refers to the ability to understand and explain the reasoning behind a machine learning model's predictions. It is an important consideration when selecting algorithms, especially in high-stakes domains such as healthcare, finance, and criminal justice.
Several factors influence the need for interpretability, including transparency and explainability, domain knowledge and model complexity, regulatory and legal requirements, and stakeholder trust and acceptance. Models such as decision trees and linear regression are inherently more interpretable, while complex neural networks are often considered black boxes, which are learning models characterized by their lack of transparency.
There is typically a trade-off between model interpretability and predictive performance. While deep learning models can achieve state-of-the-art accuracy, they might lack the transparency required in certain applications. You must carefully balance these factors based on your specific use case and requirements.
When selecting a model, consider the level of interpretability needed for your application. In some cases, you might prioritize accuracy over interpretability, while in others, the ability to explain model decisions might be paramount. Understanding this balance is necessary for building trustworthy and effective machine learning solutions.

There is typically a trade-off between model interpretability and predictive performance. While deep learning models can achieve state-of-the-art accuracy, they might lack the transparency required in certain applications. You must carefully balance these factors based on your specific use case and requirements.
When selecting a model, consider the level of interpretability needed for your application. In some cases, you might prioritize accuracy over interpretability, while in others, the ability to explain model decisions might be paramount. Understanding this balance is necessary for building trustworthy and effective machine learning solutions.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://aws.amazon.com/machine-learning/features/interpretability/
~
~Alt text:
~A diagram showing two scales, one for "Accuracy" and one for "Interpretability", with various ML models plotted along the scales. Linear regression is high on interpretability but low on accuracy, while neural networks are high on accuracy but low on interpretability.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Discuss the importance of interpretability.
|Explain factors influencing interpretability needs.
|Highlight trade-offs between accuracy and interpretability.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
Interpretability refers to the ability to understand and explain the reasoning behind a machine learning model's predictions. It is an important consideration when selecting algorithms, especially in high-stakes domains such as healthcare, finance, and criminal justice.
Several factors influence the need for interpretability, including transparency and explainability, domain knowledge and model complexity, regulatory and legal requirements, and stakeholder trust and acceptance. Models such as decision trees and linear regression are inherently more interpretable, while complex neural networks are often considered black boxes, which are learning models characterized by their lack of transparency.
There is typically a trade-off between model interpretability and predictive performance. While deep learning models can achieve state-of-the-art accuracy, they might lack the transparency required in certain applications. You must carefully balance these factors based on your specific use case and requirements.
When selecting a model, consider the level of interpretability needed for your application. In some cases, you might prioritize accuracy over interpretability, while in others, the ability to explain model decisions might be paramount. Understanding this balance is necessary for building trustworthy and effective machine learning solutions.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://aws.amazon.com/machine-learning/features/interpretability/
~https://christophm.github.io/interpretable-ml-book/
~
~Alt text:
~Four icons representing different interpretability strategies: 1) A simple model approximating a complex one, 2) A magnifying glass zooming in on part of a model, 3) Interconnected blocks representing modular components, 4) Multiple trees combined into an ensemble.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Explain interpretable model approximation.
|Discuss local interpretability techniques.
|Describe modular design approach.
|Introduce ensemble methods for interpretability.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
To balance model interpretability and performance, developers can employ various strategies.
Interpretable model approximation involves training a simpler, more interpretable model to mimic the predictions of a complex black-box model. This can be achieved through techniques such as the following:
Knowledge distillation (transferring knowledge from a large model to a smaller one)
Model approximation (creating simplified versions that preserve core prediction behavior)
Local interpretability methods, such as Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME) and SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP), provide insights into how a model makes predictions for specific instances or subsets of data, even if the global behavior is opaque.  AWS offers explainability with SHAP using Amazon SageMaker Clarify.
The modular design approach decomposes a complex model into smaller, interpretable components, combining the strengths of different models for different tasks.
Ensemble methods combine multiple interpretable models, such as decision trees or rule-based models, potentially achieving performance comparable to complex models while retaining interpretability through the individual components.

~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
• |Explain interpretable model approximation.
• |Discuss local interpretability techniques.
• |Describe modular design approach.
• |Introduce ensemble methods for interpretability.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
To balance model interpretability and performance, developers can employ various strategies.
Interpretable model approximation involves training a simpler, more interpretable model to mimic the predictions of a complex black-box model. This can be achieved through techniques such as the following:
• Knowledge distillation (transferring knowledge from a large model to a smaller one)
• Model approximation (creating simplified versions that preserve core prediction behavior)
Local interpretability methods, such as Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME) and SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP), provide insights into how a model makes predictions for specific instances or subsets of data, even if the global behavior is opaque.  AWS offers explainability with SHAP using Amazon SageMaker Clarify.
The modular design approach decomposes a complex model into smaller, interpretable components, combining the strengths of different models for different tasks.
Ensemble methods combine multiple interpretable models, such as decision trees or rule-based models, potentially achieving performance comparable to complex models while retaining interpretability through the individual components.

paragraphs.text_content: There is often an inverse relationship between a model's interpretability and its predictive accuracy. Linear models such as regression are highly interpretable but might have limited accuracy for complex problems. On the other hand, deep neural networks can achieve state-of-the-art performance but are generally considered black boxes, lacking transparency.

paragraphs.text_content: The appropriate balance between interpretability and performance depends on the specific use case and requirements. In domains such as healthcare or finance, where decisions have significant consequences, interpretability might be prioritized over marginal accuracy gains. However, for applications where accuracy is paramount and stakeholder trust is less important, complex black-box models might be preferred.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://aws.amazon.com/machine-learning/features/interpretability/
~
~Alt text:
~A scatter plot with models plotted based on their accuracy (x-axis) and interpretability (y-axis). Linear regression and decision trees are high on interpretability but low on accuracy, while neural networks are high on accuracy but low on interpretability. Random forests and SVMs are in the middle.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Highlight the inverse relationship between interpretability and accuracy.
|Discuss trade-offs based on use case requirements.
|Emphasize the importance of finding the right balance.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
There is often an inverse relationship between a model's interpretability and its predictive accuracy. Linear models such as regression are highly interpretable but might have limited accuracy for complex problems. On the other hand, deep neural networks can achieve state-of-the-art performance but are generally considered black boxes, lacking transparency.
The appropriate balance between interpretability and performance depends on the specific use case and requirements. In domains such as healthcare or finance, where decisions have significant consequences, interpretability might be prioritized over marginal accuracy gains. However, for applications where accuracy is paramount and stakeholder trust is less important, complex black-box models might be preferred.
Ultimately, you must carefully evaluate the trade-offs and find the right balance between interpretability and performance based on the problem at hand, regulatory constraints, and stakeholder needs.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~Two icons representing structured data (a table) and unstructured data (an image, audio waveform, and text). The structured data icon is connected to traditional ML models like linear models and decision trees, while the unstructured data icon is connected to complex models like neural networks.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Explain the difference between structured and unstructured data tasks.
|Highlight typical algorithms used for each task type.
|Discuss computational requirements and cost implications.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
The characteristics of the machine learning task at hand can influence the choice of models or algorithms and their associated computational requirements.
Tasks with structured data, such as tabular data or time series, are often well-suited for traditional machine learning algorithms such as linear models, decision trees, or ensemble methods. These algorithms tend to be less computationally intensive and can often be trained efficiently on CPUs.
In contrast, tasks involving unstructured data such as images, audio, or text might require more complex models such as deep neural networks or transformer architectures. These models can be computationally demanding and might benefit from GPU acceleration or distributed computing resources, potentially increasing the overall cost.
Understanding the data characteristics and computational requirements is essential for selecting the appropriate models and optimizing resource utilization and costs.

The characteristics of the machine learning task at hand can influence the choice of models or algorithms and their associated computational requirements.
Tasks with structured data, such as tabular data or time series, are often well-suited for traditional machine learning algorithms such as linear models, decision trees, or ensemble methods. These algorithms tend to be less computationally intensive and can often be trained efficiently on CPUs.
In contrast, tasks involving unstructured data such as images, audio, or text might require more complex models such as deep neural networks or transformer architectures. These models can be computationally demanding and might benefit from GPU acceleration or distributed computing resources, potentially increasing the overall cost.
Understanding the data characteristics and computational requirements is essential for selecting the appropriate models and optimizing resource utilization and costs.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://aws.amazon.com/machine-learning/pricing/
~
~Alt text:
~A dollar sign icon representing cost considerations.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Introduce the importance of cost considerations in ML.
|Highlight the need to balance performance and cost.
|Discuss factors affecting ML costs.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
In addition to model performance and interpretability, cost is another important consideration when selecting machine learning models or algorithms. As the demand for efficient and scalable solutions grows, it becomes essential to strike a balance between achieving high predictive performance and maintaining cost-effectiveness.
Optimizing model complexity and computational resources can significantly reduce operational expenses while maintaining acceptable performance standards. Factors such as CPU and GPU requirements, task characteristics, and the ability to use auto scaling and elasticity can impact the overall cost of deploying and running machine learning models.
By carefully evaluating these factors, organizations can make informed decisions about selecting the most cost-efficient models or algorithms for their specific use cases, ensuring efficient resource utilization and maximizing cost savings.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://aws.amazon.com/machine-learning/pricing/
~
~Alt text:
~Three icons representing CPU and GPU requirements (a processor chip), task characteristics (a bar chart), and auto-scaling and elasticity (a server icon growing or shrinking in size).
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Introduce the key factors affecting ML costs.
|Explain the role of CPU compared to GPU requirements.
|Discuss the impact of task characteristics.
|Highlight the importance of auto scaling and elasticity.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
Several factors can influence the cost of deploying and running machine learning models or algorithms. To make informed decisions and optimize costs, you must consider the following:
CPU and GPU requirements: Certain tasks might benefit from GPU acceleration, which can provide significant performance gains but typically comes at a higher cost compared to CPU-based solutions.
Task characteristics: The specific requirements of your ML task, such as the complexity of the problem, the size of the dataset, and the need for real-time inference, can impact the computational resources required and, consequently, the associated costs.
Auto scaling and elasticity: The ability to dynamically adjust computing resources based on workload demands can help minimize costs by ensuring efficient resource utilization and avoiding unnecessary expenses during periods of low demand.
By carefully evaluating these factors, you can select the most cost-effective models or algorithms while balancing performance requirements and budgetary constraints.
slide_analyses.formatted_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://aws.amazon.com/machine-learning/pricing/
~
~Alt text:
~Three icons representing CPU and GPU requirements (a processor chip), task characteristics (a bar chart), and auto-scaling and elasticity (a server icon growing or shrinking in size).
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
• |Introduce the key factors affecting ML costs.
• |Explain the role of CPU compared to GPU requirements.
• |Discuss the impact of task characteristics.
• |Highlight the importance of auto scaling and elasticity.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
Several factors can influence the cost of deploying and running machine learning models or algorithms. To make informed decisions and optimize costs, you must consider the following:
• CPU and GPU requirements: Certain tasks might benefit from GPU acceleration, which can provide significant performance gains but typically comes at a higher cost compared to CPU-based solutions.
• Task characteristics: The specific requirements of your ML task, such as the complexity of the problem, the size of the dataset, and the need for real-time inference, can impact the computational resources required and, consequently, the associated costs.
• Auto scaling and elasticity: The ability to dynamically adjust computing resources based on workload demands can help minimize costs by ensuring efficient resource utilization and avoiding unnecessary expenses during periods of low demand.
By carefully evaluating these factors, you can select the most cost-effective models or algorithms while balancing performance requirements and budgetary constraints.

paragraphs.text_content: GPUs are designed for parallel processing and excel at tasks that involve matrix operations, such as deep learning and other computationally intensive algorithms. Although GPUs typically come at a higher cost, they can provide significant performance gains, making them more cost-effective in the long run for certain use cases. The specific requirements of your project should guide the decision to use GPUs. If your task involves large datasets, complex models, or real-time inference, investing in GPU resources might be more cost-effective due to the performance gains, despite the higher upfront cost.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://aws.amazon.com/machine-learning/pricing/
~
~Alt text:
~Two icons representing a CPU (a processor chip) and a GPU (a specialized graphics processor chip).
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Explain the differences between CPUs and GPUs.
|Discuss use cases suitable for CPUs.
|Highlight scenarios where GPUs might be more cost-effective.
|Emphasize the importance of evaluating project requirements.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
One important decision when deploying machine learning models or algorithms is whether to use CPUs or GPUs for the computational workloads.
CPUs are generally more cost-effective and suitable for tasks that don't require intensive computational power. They can be used for data preprocessing, feature engineering, and certain types of ML models, such as decision trees or linear models.
GPUs are designed for parallel processing and excel at tasks that involve matrix operations, such as deep learning and other computationally intensive algorithms. Although GPUs typically come at a higher cost, they can provide significant performance gains, making them more cost-effective in the long run for certain use cases. The specific requirements of your project should guide the decision to use GPUs. If your task involves large datasets, complex models, or real-time inference, investing in GPU resources might be more cost-effective due to the performance gains, despite the higher upfront cost.

~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
• |Explain the differences between CPUs and GPUs.
• |Discuss use cases suitable for CPUs.
• |Highlight scenarios where GPUs might be more cost-effective.
• |Emphasize the importance of evaluating project requirements.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
One important decision when deploying machine learning models or algorithms is whether to use CPUs or GPUs for the computational workloads.
CPUs are generally more cost-effective and suitable for tasks that don't require intensive computational power. They can be used for data preprocessing, feature engineering, and certain types of ML models, such as decision trees or linear models.
GPUs are designed for parallel processing and excel at tasks that involve matrix operations, such as deep learning and other computationally intensive algorithms. Although GPUs typically come at a higher cost, they can provide significant performance gains, making them more cost-effective in the long run for certain use cases. The specific requirements of your project should guide the decision to use GPUs. If your task involves large datasets, complex models, or real-time inference, investing in GPU resources might be more cost-effective due to the performance gains, despite the higher upfront cost.
