slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://aws.amazon.com/machine-learning/pricing/
~https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/model-parallel.html
~
~Alt text:
~Four icons representing: 1) Evaluating the need for distributed computing, 2) Optimizing models or algorithms, 3) Model compression or quantization techniques, 4) Alternative approaches like transfer learning or federated learning.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Emphasize the importance of evaluating the use case.
|Discuss optimizing models or algorithms.
|Introduce model compression and quantization techniques.
|Highlight alternative approaches such as transfer learning.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
When evaluating your ML use case, first determine if distributed computing is required. This involves assessing your data volume, model complexity, and training time requirements to decide whether single-instance training is sufficient or if you need multi-node processing.
Next, focus on optimizing your models and algorithms. This means fine-tuning hyperparameters, balancing accuracy with computational efficiency, and making sure your solution meets performance requirements while staying within resource constraints.
Consider implementing advanced optimization techniques such as model compression or quantization. These approaches can significantly reduce model size and improve efficiency while maintaining acceptable levels of accuracy, making deployment more practical and cost-effective.
Finally, explore alternative approaches such as transfer learning or federated learning. These techniques can offer significant advantages in certain scenarios, particularly when dealing with limited data, privacy constraints, or when looking to use existing pre-trained models to accelerate development.

These techniques can offer significant advantages in certain scenarios, particularly when dealing with limited data, privacy constraints, or when looking to use existing pre-trained models to accelerate development.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~https://aws.amazon.com/machine-learning/pricing/
~
~Alt text:
~An icon representing auto-scaling or elasticity, with a server icon growing or shrinking in size based on demand.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Explain the concept of distributed computing resources.
|Introduce auto scaling and elasticity.
|Highlight the cost benefits of on-demand instances.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
Large-scale machine learning tasks or accelerated training and inference processes might require using distributed computing resources, such as clusters. While these resources can provide significant performance gains, they also come with additional costs.
To optimize cost-efficiency, consider using On-Demand Instances that will run only when they are genuinely needed and can be scaled down when they are no longer required. This approach, known as auto scaling or elasticity, gives you the ability to dynamically adjust your computing resources based on workload demands, minimizing costs and ensuring efficient resource utilization.
By taking advantage of auto scaling and On-Demand Instances, you can effectively manage your distributed computing resources, reducing unnecessary expenses while still benefiting from the performance advantages when required.

Correct Answer: B Random Cut Forest
Explanation: Random Cut Forest is designed for real-time anomaly detection in streaming data. It can effectively identify unusual patterns or outliers in transaction data, making it suitable for fraud detection.
Incorrect Answers:
A. DeepAR is for time-series forecasting, not real-time anomaly detection.
C. Neural Topic Model is for topic modeling in text data, not fraud detection.
D. BlazingText is for text classification and word embeddings, not suitable for transaction data.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Explain the scenario and the options provided.
|Highlight the key features of Amazon Lex V2.
|Briefly mention the other services and why they are not suitable for this use case.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
Correct answer: B. Supervised learning (for example, random forest)
Explanation: Supervised learning, such as using a random forest algorithm, is most appropriate for this scenario. With labeled historical data of both fraudulent and legitimate transactions, a supervised model can learn to classify new transactions effectively.
Incorrect answers:
A. Unsupervised learning is less suitable when labeled data is available, because it doesn't use the known fraud labels.
C. Reinforcement learning is typically used for decision-making processes over time, not for classification tasks such as fraud detection.
D. Transfer learning is useful when limited labeled data is available in the target domain, which is not the case here.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES
|Review the scenario.||STUDENT NOTES
In this activity, you take on the role of an ML engineer at AnyCompany Consulting. The key objectives are to identify the type of ML problem for each project and select an appropriate algorithm from built-in options in Amazon SageMaker AI.
Business problem: A retail company wants to increase sales through a targeted marketing campaign. They have historical customer data, including demographics, past purchase history, and information about whether customers responded to previous campaigns.
Potential ML approaches:
Predict customer lifetime value (regression).
Pros: Gives a specific dollar amount to prioritize customers
Cons: Is a more complex model and requires more historical data
Predict the likelihood to respond to a campaign (binary classification).
Pros: Directly addresses the campaign response goal and uses a simpler model
Cons: Doesn't provide specifics on potential revenue
Segment customers into groups (unsupervised clustering).
Pros: Could reveal unexpected patterns in the customer base
Cons: Doesn't directly predict a campaign response
Predict specific product recommendations (multi-class classification).
Pros: Allows for very targeted marketing
Cons: Requires extensive product and customer data
Recommended approach: Binary classification is the recommended approach to predict the likelihood that customers will respond to the campaign.
Rationale:
This approach directly addresses the goal of improving campaign effectiveness.
You have labeled data on past campaign responses to train on.
This approach includes a simpler model that requires less data than regression.
This approach provides clear yes or no predictions to prioritize customers for the campaign.
You can translate model output into business actions.
Next steps:
Prepare historical customer and campaign response data.
Select binary classification algorithms to test (for example, Logistic Regression and Random Forest).
Evaluate model performance and business impact.
Deploy your chosen model to score customers for the upcoming campaign.
This activity demonstrates how to connect the business problem to potential ML approaches, evaluate the pros and cons, and select an appropriate framing and algorithm type. The key is tying the ML approach back to the original business goals.
slide_analyses.formatted_text_extraction:
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES
|Review the scenario.||STUDENT NOTES
In this activity, you take on the role of an ML engineer at AnyCompany Consulting. The key objectives are to identify the type of ML problem for each project and select an appropriate algorithm from built-in options in Amazon SageMaker AI.
Business problem: A retail company wants to increase sales through a targeted marketing campaign. They have historical customer data, including demographics, past purchase history, and information about whether customers responded to previous campaigns.
Potential ML approaches:
• Predict customer lifetime value (regression).
  • Pros: Gives a specific dollar amount to prioritize customers
  • Cons: Is a more complex model and requires more historical data
• Predict the likelihood to respond to a campaign (binary classification).
  • Pros: Directly addresses the campaign response goal and uses a simpler model
  • Cons: Doesn't provide specifics on potential revenue
• Segment customers into groups (unsupervised clustering).
  • Pros: Could reveal unexpected patterns in the customer base
  • Cons: Doesn't directly predict a campaign response
• Predict specific product recommendations (multi-class classification).
  • Pros: Allows for very targeted marketing
  • Cons: Requires extensive product and customer data
Recommended approach: Binary classification is the recommended approach to predict the likelihood that customers will respond to the campaign.
Rationale:
• This approach directly addresses the goal of improving campaign effectiveness.
• You have labeled data on past campaign responses to train on.
• This approach includes a simpler model that requires less data than regression.
• This approach provides clear yes or no predictions to prioritize customers for the campaign.
• You can translate model output into business actions.
Next steps:
1. Prepare historical customer and campaign response data.
1. Select binary classification algorithms to test (for example, Logistic Regression and Random Forest).
1. Evaluate model performance and business impact.
1. Deploy your chosen model to score customers for the upcoming campaign.
This activity demonstrates how to connect the business problem to potential ML approaches, evaluate the pros and cons, and select an appropriate framing and algorithm type. The key is tying the ML approach back to the original business goals.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~Ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Slide Description:
~This slide presents three tasks related to customer behavior prediction and asks students to identify the type of supervised learning problem for each task from a list of options.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Explain each of the three tasks and their context.
|Guide students through the process of identifying problem types.
|Discuss the differences between binary classification, multi-class classification, regression, and time-series forecasting.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
This slide presents three distinct supervised learning tasks related to customer behavior prediction. Your goal is to correctly identify the type of problem for each task:
A. Predict whether an income is below a certain threshold: You have already determined that this is your business case, and it is a binary classification challenge.
Predicting the dates of future purchases: This task involves forecasting specific points in time.
Predicting customer responses to discount types: This task requires categorizing customers into multiple groups based on their likely response.
Predicting a purchase amount with a discount: This task involves estimating a continuous numerical value.
Understanding how to classify ML problems is important for selecting appropriate algorithms and designing effective solutions. Select the problem type for tasks B, C, and D. Consider the nature of the output (categorical, continuous, or time-based) and the number of possible outcomes when determining the problem type.

• |Guide students through the process of identifying problem types.
• |Discuss the differences between binary classification, multi-class classification, regression, and time-series forecasting.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
This slide presents three distinct supervised learning tasks related to customer behavior prediction. Your goal is to correctly identify the type of problem for each task:
A. Predict whether an income is below a certain threshold: You have already determined that this is your business case, and it is a binary classification challenge.
1. Predicting the dates of future purchases: This task involves forecasting specific points in time.
1. Predicting customer responses to discount types: This task requires categorizing customers into multiple groups based on their likely response.
1. Predicting a purchase amount with a discount: This task involves estimating a continuous numerical value.
Understanding how to classify ML problems is important for selecting appropriate algorithms and designing effective solutions. Select the problem type for tasks B, C, and D. Consider the nature of the output (categorical, continuous, or time-based) and the number of possible outcomes when determining the problem type.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~Ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~This slide shows the same three tasks from the previous slide but now with their identified problem types. It includes a QR code linking to SageMaker AI built-in algorithms documentation.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Review the identified problem types for each task.
|Guide students on using the SageMaker AI documentation to find relevant algorithms.
|Discuss the importance of algorithm selection in the ML workflow.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
The problem type for each task is:
Predicting the dates of future purchases: This task involves forecasting specific points in time, indicating a time-series problem.
Predicting customer responses to discount types: This task requires categorizing customers into multiple groups based on their likely response, suggesting a multi-class classification problem.
Predicting a purchase amount with a discount: This task involves estimating a continuous numerical value, pointing to a regression problem.
Now that you’ve identified the problem types, the next step is to list suitable SageMaker AI built-in algorithms for each task:
Use the provided QR code to access the SageMaker AI documentation on built-in algorithms. When selecting algorithms, consider factors such as the following:
Data characteristics (for example, size, feature types, and sparsity)
Model interpretability requirements
Computational resources available
Specific strengths of each algorithm (for example, handling of categorical variables and ability to capture non-linear relationships)
Matching the right algorithm to each problem type is important for building effective ML models in SageMaker AI.
For more information about SageMaker AI built-in models and algorithms, see “Built-In Algorithms and Pretrained Models in Amazon SageMaker” at https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html.
slide_analyses.formatted_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~Ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~This slide shows the same three tasks from the previous slide but now with their identified problem types. It includes a QR code linking to SageMaker AI built-in algorithms documentation.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
• |Review the identified problem types for each task.
• |Guide students on using the SageMaker AI documentation to find relevant algorithms.
• |Discuss the importance of algorithm selection in the ML workflow.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
The problem type for each task is:
1. Predicting the dates of future purchases: This task involves forecasting specific points in time, indicating a time-series problem.
1. Predicting customer responses to discount types: This task requires categorizing customers into multiple groups based on their likely response, suggesting a multi-class classification problem.
1. Predicting a purchase amount with a discount: This task involves estimating a continuous numerical value, pointing to a regression problem.
Now that you’ve identified the problem types, the next step is to list suitable SageMaker AI built-in algorithms for each task:
Use the provided QR code to access the SageMaker AI documentation on built-in algorithms. When selecting algorithms, consider factors such as the following:
• Data characteristics (for example, size, feature types, and sparsity)
• Model interpretability requirements
• Computational resources available
• Specific strengths of each algorithm (for example, handling of categorical variables and ability to capture non-linear relationships)
Matching the right algorithm to each problem type is important for building effective ML models in SageMaker AI.
For more information about SageMaker AI built-in models and algorithms, see “Built-In Algorithms and Pretrained Models in Amazon SageMaker” at https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html.

slide_analyses.raw_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~Ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~This slide shows a completed table with three tasks, their problem types, and corresponding SageMaker AI built-in algorithms for each task.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Review the sample solution for activity 3.
|Discuss the selected algorithms for each problem type.
|Highlight the versatility of some algorithms across problem types.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
This slide presents a sample solution for activity 3, showcasing appropriate SageMaker AI built-in algorithms for each of the three supervised learning tasks. For the time-series forecasting task of predicting future purchase dates, the DeepAR forecasting algorithm is suggested. This algorithm is specifically designed for time-series data and can handle multiple related time series simultaneously.
For the multi-class classification problem of determining customer response to different discount levels, several algorithms are proposed: K-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN), Linear learner, and XGBoost. These algorithms can effectively handle classification tasks with multiple classes.
The regression task of predicting purchase amounts also lists K-Nearest Neighbors, Linear learner, and XGBoost as suitable algorithms. This demonstrates that some algorithms, such as XGBoost, are versatile and can be applied to various problem types.
slide_analyses.formatted_text_extraction:
~Developer Notes:
~Ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/algos.html
~
~Alt text:
~This slide shows a completed table with three tasks, their problem types, and corresponding SageMaker AI built-in algorithms for each task.
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
• |Review the sample solution for activity 3.
• |Discuss the selected algorithms for each problem type.
• |Highlight the versatility of some algorithms across problem types.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
This slide presents a sample solution for activity 3, showcasing appropriate SageMaker AI built-in algorithms for each of the three supervised learning tasks. For the time-series forecasting task of predicting future purchase dates, the DeepAR forecasting algorithm is suggested. This algorithm is specifically designed for time-series data and can handle multiple related time series simultaneously.
For the multi-class classification problem of determining customer response to different discount levels, several algorithms are proposed: K-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN), Linear learner, and XGBoost. These algorithms can effectively handle classification tasks with multiple classes.
The regression task of predicting purchase amounts also lists K-Nearest Neighbors, Linear learner, and XGBoost as suitable algorithms. This demonstrates that some algorithms, such as XGBoost, are versatile and can be applied to various problem types.

~Alt text:
~A slide with a list of learning objectives covered in the module
~
|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:
|Recap the key learning objectives.
|Highlight the importance of the topics covered.
|Encourage students to apply the knowledge gained.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
By completing this module, you should now be able to do the following:
Select AWS AI services to solve common business needs. You can identify and choose the appropriate AWS AI services tailored to specific business requirements, ensuring optimal solutions for diverse industry scenarios.
Identify specific use cases for SageMaker AI built-in algorithms. You can recognize and apply the SageMaker AI pre-built algorithms to relevant business use cases, using their capabilities to effectively solve problems.
Select the most appropriate ML model algorithms to solve common business needs. You can choose the best-suited ML algorithms from AWS offerings to address typical business challenges, considering factors such as accuracy, scalability, and performance.
Describe the role that interpretability plays during model or algorithm selection. You can explain the importance of interpretability in the selection process of models or algorithms, ensuring transparency and trust in AI-driven decisions.
Select the most cost-efficient models or algorithms to solve common business needs. You can identify and implement the most cost-effective ML models or algorithms available on AWS, balancing performance with budgetary constraints.
The knowledge and skills acquired in this module will empower you to make informed decisions when building machine learning solutions on AWS, ensuring optimal performance, scalability, and cost-effectiveness.

|INSTRUCTOR NOTES:

• |Highlight the importance of the topics covered.
• |Encourage students to apply the knowledge gained.
|
|STUDENT NOTES:
By completing this module, you should now be able to do the following:
• Select AWS AI services to solve common business needs. You can identify and choose the appropriate AWS AI services tailored to specific business requirements, ensuring optimal solutions for diverse industry scenarios.
• Identify specific use cases for SageMaker AI built-in algorithms. You can recognize and apply the SageMaker AI pre-built algorithms to relevant business use cases, using their capabilities to effectively solve problems.
• Select the most appropriate ML model algorithms to solve common business needs. You can choose the best-suited ML algorithms from AWS offerings to address typical business challenges, considering factors such as accuracy, scalability, and performance.
• Describe the role that interpretability plays during model or algorithm selection. You can explain the importance of interpretability in the selection process of models or algorithms, ensuring transparency and trust in AI-driven decisions.
• Select the most cost-efficient models or algorithms to solve common business needs. You can identify and implement the most cost-effective ML models or algorithms available on AWS, balancing performance with budgetary constraints.
The knowledge and skills acquired in this module will empower you to make informed decisions when building machine learning solutions on AWS, ensuring optimal performance, scalability, and cost-effectiveness.
